question: Question 1 At least one eigenvalue of a singular matrix is
solution: For singular matrix [latex] |A|=0 [/latex] According to properties of eigen value Product of eigen values [latex]=|A|=0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex]  Atleast one of the eigen value is zero.

question: Question 2 At x = 0, the function [latex]f(x)=\left | x \right |[/latex]  has
solution: The graph of  |x|  is from the graph we can say that |x| has minimum at x=0

question: Question 3 Curl of vector [latex]V(x,y,z)= 2x^{2}i+3z^{2}j+y^{3}k[/latex]  at [latex]x=y=z=1[/latex]  is
solution: Curl of vector[latex] =\left|\begin{array}{ccc} i & j & k \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ 2 x^{2} & 3 z^{2} & y^{3} \end{array}\right| [/latex] [latex] =i\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(y^{3}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(3 z^{2}\right)\right]+j\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(y^{3}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(2 x^{2}\right)\right][/latex] [latex] +k\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(3z^{2}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(2 x^{2}\right)\right] [/latex] [latex] =i\left[3 y^{2}-6 z\right]-[10]+k[0+0] [/latex] [latex] \text { At } x=1, y=1 \text { and } z=1 [/latex] [latex] \text { Curl }=i\left(3 \times 1^{2}-6 \times 1\right)=-3 i[/latex]

question: Question 4 The Laplace transform of [latex]e^{i5t}[/latex]  where [latex]i=\sqrt{-1}[/latex]  is

Question 5 Three vendors were asked to supply a very high precision component. The respective probabilities of their meeting the strict design specifications are 0.8, 0.7 and 0.5.  Each vendor supplies one component. The probability that out of total three components supplied by the vendors, at least one will meet the design specification is ___________
solution: Probability of atleast one meet the specification [latex] \begin{aligned} &=1-(\bar{A} \cap \bar{B} \cap \bar{C}) \\ &=1-(0.2 \times 0.3 \times 0.5) \\ &=0.97 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 6 A small ball of mass 1 kg moving with a velocity of 12 m/s undergoes a direct central impact with a stationary ball of mass 2 kg. The impact is perfectly elastic. The speed (in m/s) of 2 kg mass ball after the impact will be ____________
solution: 1. Conserving linear momentum [latex] \begin{aligned} 1 \times 12 &=1 \times V_{1}+2 \times V_{2} \\ 12 &=V_{1}+2 V_{2}\qquad \ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] 2. Velocity of approach = Velocity of seperation [latex] 12-0=v_{2}-v_{1}[/latex] [latex] V_{2}-V_{1}=12 \qquad \ldots(ii)[/latex] From (i) and (ii), we get [latex] v_{2}=8 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 7 A rod is subjected to a uni-axial load within linear elastic limit. When the change in the stress is   200 MPa, the change in the strain is 0.001. If the Poisson's ratio of the rod is 0.3, the modulus of rigidity (in GPa) is ________________
solution: With in linear elastic limit [latex] \sigma=E \in[/latex] [latex] E \rightarrow \text{ slope of } \sigma \text{ vs }\in \text{ curve}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} E &=\frac{d \sigma}{d \epsilon}=\frac{200}{0.001}=200 \mathrm{GPa} \\ E &=2 G[1+\mu] \\ G &=\frac{E}{2(1+\mu)}=\frac{200}{2(1+0.3)}=\frac{100}{1.3} \\ &=76.9230 \mathrm{GPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 8 A gas is stored in a cylindrical tank of inner radius 7 m and wall thickness 50 mm. The gage pressure of the gas is 2 MPa. The maximum shear stress (in MPa) in the wall is
solution: Maximum shear stress in the wall [latex] =\frac{\sigma_{1}}{2}=\frac{p d}{4 t}=\frac{2 \times 14 \times 1000}{4 \times 50}=140 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]

question: Question 9 The number of degrees of freedom of the planetary gear train shown in the figure is
solution: Degree of freedom: [latex]F=3(l-1)-2 j-h [/latex] [latex] =3(4-1)-2 \times 3-1=2[/latex]

question: Question 10 In a spring-mass system, the mass is m and the spring constant is k. The critical damping coefficient of the system is 0.1 kg/s. In another spring-mass system, the mass is 2m and the spring constant is 8k. The critical damping coefficient (in kg/s) of this system is ____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \xi &=\frac{C}{2 \sqrt{m k}} \\ C &=2 \xi \sqrt{m k} \\ \frac{C_{2}}{C_{1}} &=\frac{2 \xi_{2} \sqrt{m_{2} k_{2}}}{2 \xi_{1} \sqrt{m_{1} k_{1}}} \\ \frac{C_{2}}{0.1} &=\frac{2 \times 1 \sqrt{2 m \times 8 k}}{2 \times 1 \sqrt{m \times k}} \\ C_{2} &=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 11 The uniaxial yield stress of a material is 300 MPa. According to von Mises criterion, the shear yield stress (in MPa) of the material is _______
solution: According to Von-Mises criterion, [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{y} &=\frac{\sigma_{y}}{\sqrt{3}} \\ &=\frac{300}{\sqrt{3}}=173.1 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 12 If the fluid velocity for a potential flow is given by [latex]V(x,y)=u(x,y)i+v(x,y)j[/latex]  with usual notations, then the slope of the potential line at [latex](x,y)[/latex]  is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} d \phi&=\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x} d x+\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial y} d y\\ \therefore \qquad \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x}&=-u\\ \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial y}&=-v \\ \therefore \qquad d \phi&=-u d x-v d y \\ \text { If } \phi&=\text { constant, } d \phi=0 \\ \therefore \quad\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)_{\phi}&=-\frac{u}{v} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 13 Which of the following statements regarding a Rankine cycle with reheating are TRUE? (i) increase in average temperature of heat addition (ii) reduction in thermal efficiency (iii) drier steam at the turbine exit
solution: Rankine cycle with reheating: Advantages: (i) Increase in a average temperature of heat addition. (ii) Increase in thermal efficiency. (iii) Drier steam at the turbine exit i.e., decrease in moisture content of the steam at the low-pressure turbine exit, reducing the turbine blade erosion.

question: Question 14 Within a boundary layer for a steady incompressible flow, the Bernoulli equation
solution: Within boundary layer, Bernoulli's equation is not valid because due to friction, flow is irrotional

options.A: holds because the flow is steady
options.B: holds because the flow is incompressible
options.C: holds because the flow is transitional
options.D: does not hold because the flow is frictional

question: Question 15 If a foam insulation is added to a 4 cm outer diameter pipe as shown in the figure, the critical radius of insulation (in cm) is _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} k_{\text {loam }}&=0.1 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK}\\ h_{0}&=2 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Critical radius, [latex] \begin{aligned} r_{c} &=\frac{k_{\text {foam }}}{h_{0}} \text { for a pipe } \\ &=\frac{0.1}{2}=0.05 \mathrm{m}=5 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 16 In the laminar flow of air (Pr = 0.7) over a heated plate, if [latex]\delta[/latex] and [latex]\delta_{r}[/latex]  denote, respectively, the 
hydrodynamic and thermal boundary layer thicknesses, then
solution: Prandtl number, [latex] \begin{aligned} P r&=0.7\\ \text{also}\quad \mathrm{Pr}&=\frac{\delta}{\delta_{r}}\\ \therefore 0.7&=\frac{\delta}{\delta_{r}}\\ \text{or }\quad \delta&=0.7 \delta_{r}\\ \therefore \delta& \lt \delta_{r}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 17 The COP of a Carnot heat pump operating between 6 [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] and 37 [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] is ___________
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{2} &=6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(6+273) \mathrm{K} \\ &=279 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{1} &=37^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(37+273) \mathrm{K} \\ &=310 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} (\mathrm{COP})_{\mathrm{HP}} &=\frac{T_{1}}{T_{1}-T_{2}}=\frac{310}{310-279} \\ &=10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 18 The Van der Waals equation of state is [latex](p+\frac{a}{v^{2}})(v-b)=RT[/latex]  where p is pressure, v is specific volume, T is temperature and R is characteristic gas constant. The SI unit of a is
solution: [latex]p+\frac{a}{v^{2}},[/latex] where both the terms p and [latex]\frac{a}{v^{2}} [/latex]have same unit. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \qquad p &=\frac{a}{v^{2}} \\ \frac{N}{m^{2}} &=\frac{a}{\left(m^{3} / k g\right)^{2}} \\ \frac{k g m}{s^{2}} \times \frac{1}{m^{2}} &=\frac{a \times(k g)^{2}}{m^{6}}\\ \text{or}\quad a&=m^{5} / k g s^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 19 A rope-brake dynamometer attached to the crank shaft of an I.C. engine measures a brake power of 10 kW when the speed of rotation of the shaft is 400 rad/s. The shaft torque (in N-m) sensed by the dynamometer is ___________
solution: Brake power = Brake torque x angular velocity [latex]\begin{aligned} P&=T\omega \\ T&= \frac{P}{\omega }=\frac{P}{\left ( \frac{2 \pi N}{60} \right )}\\ &= \frac{10,000}{400}=25Nm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 The atomic packing factor for a material with body centered cubic structure is __________
solution: Atomic packing factor [latex] =\frac{\text { volume occupied by } N_{\text {average }}}{\text { Volume of unit cell }} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{N_{\text {average }} \times \frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}}{a^{3}} [/latex] for bec structrue, [latex] a=\frac{4 r}{\sqrt{3}} and N_{\text {average }}=2 \Rightarrow A.P.F. =0.68[/latex]

question: Question 21 The primary mechanism of material removal in electrochemical machining (ECM) is
Question 22 Which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: GO' gauge controls the lower limit of a hole.

options.A: The 'GO' gage controls the upper limit of a hole
options.B: The 'NO GO' gage controls the lower limit of a shaft
options.C: The 'GO' gage controls the lower limit of a hole
options.D: The 'NO GO' gage controls the lower limit of a hole

question: Question 23 During the development of a product, an entirely new process plan is made based on design logic, examination of geometry and tolerance information. This type of process planning is known as
solution: A generative manufacturing process different from a traditional manufacturing process develops a product with the addition of material instead of removal of the excess material as in case of a traditional manufacturing process. In the generative manufacturing process, plans are generated by means of decision logic, formulas, technology algorithm and geometry-based data to perform uniquely the many processing decision for converting a part from raw material to a finished state. There are two major components of a generative process planning system. A geometry-based coding scheme. Process knowledge in the form of decision logic and data. Geometry-based coding scheme: The objective of a geometric based coding scheme is to define all geometric features for all process related surfaces together with feature dimensions, locations, tolerances and the surface finish desired on the features. Advantage of Generative Manufacturing Process: No tools and fixtures are required. No restriction on geometry of the part shape exists. Composite parts and assemblies can be produced in one go. Small batch production of complex parts is economically viable.

question: Question 24 Annual demand of a product is 50000 units and the ordering cost is Rs. 7000 per order.  Considering the basic economic order quantity model, the economic order quantity is 10000 units. When the annual inventory cost is minimized, the annual inventory holding cost (in Rs.) is _______
solution: For minimum annual inventory cost, Ordering cost = Holding cost [latex] 7000 \times [/latex] number of order = holding cost or Holding cost [latex] =7000 \times \frac{50000}{10000} [/latex] = 35,000

question: Question 25 Sales data of a product is given in the following table: Regarding forecast for the month of June, which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: As regression follow a pattern [latex] \text{(forecast)}_{\text {June }} [/latex] according to regression [latex]\gt 25[/latex] but according to moving average, [latex] T_{\text {June }} \lt 25[/latex]

options.A: Moving average will forecast a higher value compared to regression.
options.B: Higher the value of order N, the greater will be the forecast value by moving average.
options.C: Exponential smoothing will forecast a higher value compared to regression.
options.D: Regression will forecast a higher value compared to moving average.

question: Question 26 The chance of a student passing an exam is 20%. The chance of a student passing the exam and getting above 90% marks in it is 5%. GIVEN that a student passes the examination, the probability that the student gets above 90% marks is
solution: Given, p( passing the exam)=0.2 p( passing the exam [latex]\cap>90 \%[/latex])=0.05 The desired probability [latex] =p([latex]>90 \% |[/latex] passing the exam ) [latex] =\frac{p(\text { passing the exam} \cap>90 \%)}{p(\text { passing the exam })} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{0.05}{0.2}=\frac{1}{4}[/latex]

question: Question 27 The surface integral [latex]\iint_{s} (1/\pi) (9xi-3yj)\cdot n dS[/latex]  over the sphere given by [latex]x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=9[/latex]   is ______
solution: Accodring to gauge divergence theorem [latex] \iint_{S} \frac{1}{\pi}(9 x i-3 y j) \cdot n d S \left.=\frac{1}{\pi} \int \operatorname{divergence}(9 x i-3 yj)\right) \cdot d v [/latex] [latex] =\frac{1}{\pi}[9-3] \times \frac{4}{3} \pi\left[r^{3}\right] [/latex] r =3    [given] [latex] =\frac{1}{\pi} \times 6 \times \frac{4}{3} \pi \times 27=216[/latex]

question: Question 28 Consider the following differential equation: [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t}= -5y[/latex] ; initial condition:y=2 at t=0. The value of  y at t = 3 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d y}{d t} &=-5 y \\ \int \frac{d y}{y} &=-\int 5 d t \\ \ln y &=-5 t+C \\ \text{at} \qquad t &=0 \\ y&=2 \\ \ln 2&=C \\ \text{So,} \quad \ln y&=-5 t+\ln 2 \\ \ln \frac{y}{2} &=-5 t \\ \frac{y}{2} &=e^{-5 t} \\ y &=2 e^{-5 t} \\ at \qquad t &=3 \\ y&=2 e^{-15} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 The values of function  f (x) at 5 discrete points are given below: Using Trapezoidal rule with step size of 0.1, the value of [latex]\int_{0}^{0.4} f(x) dx[/latex]  is

Question 30 The initial velocity of an object is 40 m/s. The acceleration a of the object is given by the following expression: a=-0.1v, where v is the instantaneous velocity of the object. The velocity of the object after 3 seconds will  be _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} u &=40 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ a &=-0.1 \mathrm{v} \\ V &=? \\ t &=3 \mathrm{s} \\ a &=\frac{d v}{d t}=-0.1 \mathrm{v} \\ \int_{40}^{v} \frac{d v}{v} &=\int_{0}^{3}-0.1 d t \\\;[\ln v]_{40}^{v} &=-0.1[t] \\ \ln v-\ln 40 &=-0.1[3.0]=-0.3 \\ \ln v &=\ln 40-0.3 \\ \ln v &=3.38887 \\\text{or}\qquad v &=e^{3.38887}=29.63 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 A cantilever beam OP is connected to another beam PQ with a pin joint as shown in the figure. A load of 10 kN is applied at the mid-point of PQ. The magnitude of bending moment (in kN-m) at fixed end O is
solution: At hinge moment releases Taking summation of all forces [latex] P_{V}+R_{Q}=10[/latex] Taking moment of all forces about Q [latex] M=\underset{clockwise}{\left(P_{V} \times 1\right)}-\underset{anticlockwise}{(10 \times 0.5)}[/latex] At equilibrium M=0 [latex] \begin{array}{rl} \therefore \quad 0 & =\left(P_{V} \times 1\right)-5 \\ P_{V} & =5 \mathrm{kN} \end{array}[/latex] Summation of all vertical forces is zero. [latex] \therefore \quad O_{V}+P_{V}=0 [/latex] Summation of Moments of all forces at equilibrium is zero. [latex] \therefore \quad\underset{clockwise}{+M}+\underset{clockwise}{P_{v}\times 2}=0[/latex] [latex] \therefore M=-P_{V} \times 2[/latex] [latex] \text{where}\quad P_{V}=-5 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] [latex] \therefore M=10 \mathrm{kN}[/latex]

question: Question 32 For the truss shown in the figure, the magnitude of the force (in kN) in the member SR is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_{P} &=0 \\ 30 \times 2 &=R_{O} \times 3 \\ R_{O} &=20 \mathrm{N} \\ R_{P} &=10 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex] Using method of section Considering moment about point T, which is zero [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{Q} \times 1 &=F_{R S} \times 1 \\ F_{B S} &=R_{Q}=20 \mathrm{N} \text { compressive } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 A cantilever beam with square cross-section of 6 mm side is subjected to a load of 2 kN normal to the top surface as shown in the figure. The Young's modulus of elasticity of the material of the beam is 210 GPa. The magnitude of slope (in radian) at Q (20 mm from the fixed end) is ________
solution: Slope [latex]\theta_{Q}-\theta_{0}=\frac{1}{E I}[\text { Area of diagram till } Q] [/latex] Area of diagram till " Q " [latex] \left[\frac{1}{2} \times 100 \times 2 \times 10^{5}\right]-\left[\frac{1}{2} \times 80 \times y\right][/latex] Calculating; y from properties of similar triangles. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{y}{2 \times 10^{5}} &=\frac{80}{100} \\ y &=160,000 \mathrm{Nmm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Area of diagram till Q [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow\left[1 / 2 \times 100 \times 2 \times 10^{5}\right]-[1 / 2 \times 80 \times 160,000] \\ =3600000 \mathrm{N} . \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \theta_{Q}=\frac{1}{210 \times 10^{3} \times I} \times 3600000 \\ I=\frac{b d^{3}}{12}=\frac{b^{4}}{12}=\frac{b^{4}}{12}=108 \mathrm{mm}^{4} \\ \theta_{Q}=\frac{1}{210 \times 10^{3} \times 108} \times 3600000 \\ =0.1587 \mathrm{rad} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 34 In a plane stress condition, the components of stress at a point are [latex]\sigma_{x}=20 MPa[/latex] ,[latex]\sigma_{y}=80 MPa[/latex] and [latex]\tau _{xy}=40 MPa[/latex] . The maximum shear stress (in MPa) at the point is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} \sigma_{1,2}=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}\right)^{2}+4 \tau_{x y}^{2}}\right] \\ =\frac{1}{2}[100 \pm \sqrt{(60)^{2}+4 \times 40^{2}}] \\ \sigma_{1}=100 \\ \sigma_{2}=0 \\ \tau_{\max }=\sigma_{1} / 2=50 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 35 In a certain slider-crank mechanism, lengths of crank and connecting rod are equal. If the crank rotates with a uniform angular speed of 14 rad/s and the crank length is 300 mm, the maximum acceleration of the slider (in m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]) is ___________
solution: [latex]a=r \omega^{2}\left[\cos \theta+\frac{\cos 2 \theta}{n}\right] [/latex] [latex] \text{at} \quad \theta=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} a &\Rightarrow a_{\max } \\ a_{\max } &=r \omega^{2}\left[1+\frac{1}{n}\right] \\ n &=\frac{l}{r}=1 \\ a_{\max } &=2 r \omega^{2}=2 \times 0.3 \times 14^{2} \\ &=117.6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 A single-degree-freedom spring-mass system is subjected to a sinusoidal force of 10 N amplitude and frequency [latex]\omega[/latex] along the axis of the spring. The stiffness of the spring is 150 N/m, damping factor is 0.2 and the undamped natural frequency is 10[latex]\omega[/latex].  At steady state, the amplitude of vibration (in m) is approximately
solution: [latex]A=\frac{F_{0} / s}{\sqrt{\left[1-\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}\right]^{2}+\left(2 \xi \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}}}[/latex] data given [latex] \begin{array}{c} F=10 \mathrm{N} \\ S=150 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \\ \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}=\frac{\omega}{10 \omega}=0.1 \\ \varepsilon=0.2 \\ \Rightarrow A=\frac{10 / 150}{\sqrt{\left[1-(0.1)^{2}\right]^{2}+[2 \times 0.2 \times 0.1]^{2}}}=0.07 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 37 A hollow shaft of 1 m length is designed to transmit a power of 30 kW at 700 rpm. The maximum permissible angle of twist in the shaft is [latex]1^{\circ}[/latex]. The inner diameter of the shaft is 0.7 times the outer diameter. The modulus of rigidity is 80 GPa. The outside diameter (in mm) of the shaft is__________
solution: Given data, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=30 \mathrm{kW} \\ N &=700 \mathrm{rpm} \\ \frac{2 \pi \mathrm{NT}}{60} &=30 \times 10^{3}=P\\ \text { or } \quad T&=409.25 \mathrm{Nm} \\ \theta=& \frac{T L}{G J} \\ \therefore \frac{1 \times \pi}{180}&=\frac{409.25 \times 10^{3} \times 10^{3} \times 32}{\pi \times\left(d_{0}\right)^{4}\left(1-0.7^{4}\right) \times 80 \times 10^{3}} \\ \text { or } \quad d_{0}&= 44.5212  \mathrm{mm}  \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 A hollow shaft ([latex]d_{o}[/latex] = 2[latex]d_{i}[/latex]  where [latex]d_{o}[/latex] and [latex]d_{i}[/latex] are the outer and inner diameters respectively) needs to transmit 20 kW power at 3000 RPM. If the maximum permissible shear stress is 30 MPa, [latex]d_{o}[/latex]  is
solution: Given data, [latex]\begin{aligned} d_{o} &=2 d_{i} \\ k &=\frac{d_{i}}{d_{o}}=0.5 \\ P &=20 \mathrm{kW} \\ N &=3000 \mathrm{RPM} \\ \frac{2 \pi \mathrm{NT}}{60} &=P \\ \text{or}\quad T &=\frac{60 \times 20 \times 10^{3}}{2 \pi \times 3000}\\ \Rightarrow & 63.66197 \mathrm{Nm} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tau_{\max } &=\frac{16 T}{\pi d_{0}^{3}\left(1-k^{4}\right)} \\ 30 &=\frac{16 \times 63.66197 \times 10^{3}}{\pi \times d_{0}^{3}\left(1-0.5^{4}\right)} \\ \text { or } \quad d_{0} &=22.59 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 The total emissive power of a surface is 500 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] at a temperature [latex]T_{1}[/latex] and 1200 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] at a temperature [latex]T_{2}[/latex], where the temperatures are in Kelvin. Assuming the emissivity of the surface to be  constant, the ratio of the temperatures [latex]\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}[/latex]
solution: E(emmisive power) [latex] \propto T^{4} \quad(\because \in=\text { Constant }) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}&=\left(\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}\right)^{4} \\ \text{or} \quad \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}&=\left(\frac{500}{1200}\right)^{1 / 4}=0.803 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 The head loss for a laminar incompressible flow through a horizontal circular pipe is [latex]h_{1}[/latex]. Pipe length and fluid remaining the same, if the average flow velocity doubles and the pipe diameter reduces to half its previous value, the head loss is[latex]h_{2}[/latex] . The ratio [latex]\frac{h_{2}}{h_{1}}[/latex]  is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Head loss: } & h_{f}=\frac{32 \mu \bar{u} L}{\rho g D^{2}} \\ & h_{1}=\frac{32 \mu \bar{u} L}{\rho g D^{2}}\\ \text{and }\quad h_{2}&=\frac{32 \mu \times 2 \bar{u} L}{\rho g(D / 2)^{2}} \\ &=\frac{32 \mu 2 \bar{u} L \times 4}{\rho g D^{2}}=\frac{8 \times 32 \mu \pi L}{\rho g D^{2}} \\ \frac{h_{2}}{h_{1}} &=\frac{8 \times 32 \mu \bar{u} L}{\rho g D^{2}} \times \frac{\rho g D^{2}}{32 \mu \bar{U} L}=8 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 For a fully developed laminar flow of water (dynamic viscosity 0.001 Pa-s) through a pipe of radius 5 cm, the axial pressure gradient is -10 Pa/m. The magnitude of axial velocity (in m/s) at a radial location of 0.2 cm is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mu &=0.001 \mathrm{Pa}-\mathrm{s} \\ R &=5 \mathrm{cm}=0.05 \mathrm{m} \\ \frac{\partial p}{\partial x} &=-10 \mathrm{Pa} / \mathrm{m} \\ r &=0.2 \mathrm{cm}=0.002 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] For incompressible laminar flow throughpipe Local velocity, [latex] \begin{aligned} u &=-\frac{1}{4 \mu} \frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\left[R^{2}-r^{2}\right] \\ &=-\frac{1}{4 \times 0.001} \times(-10)\left[(0.05)^{2}-(0.002)^{2}\right] \\ &=6.24 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 A balanced counterflow heat exchanger has a surface area of 20 [latex]m^{2}[/latex]  and overall heat transfer coefficient of 20 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] -K. Air ([latex]C_{p}[/latex] =1000 J/kg-K) entering at 0.4 kg/s and 280 K is to be preheated by the air leaving the system at 0.4 kg/s and 300 K. The outlet temperature (in K) of the preheated air is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} A&=20 \mathrm{m}^{3} ; \quad U=20 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} ; \quad c_{p h}=1000 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K} \\ m_{c}&=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} ; \quad T_{c 1}=280 \mathrm{K} ; \quad m_{h}=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \\ T_{h 2}&=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{c 2}=? \end{aligned}[/latex] By energy balance, Heat lost by hot fluid = Heat gained by cold fluid [latex] m_{h} c_{p h}\left(T_{h 1}-T_{h 2}\right)=m_{c} c_{p c}\left(T_{c 2}-T_{c 1}\right) [/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad T_{h 1}-T_{h 2}=T_{c 2}-T_{c 1} \quad \because m_{h} c_{p h}=m_{c} c_{p c}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{h 1}-T_{c 2} &=T_{h 2}-T_{c 1} \\ \theta_{1} &=\theta_{2} \\ \text { If } \theta_{1}&=\theta_{2} \text { , then } L M T D=\theta_{1}=\theta_{2} \\ Q &=A U L M T D \\ Q &=A U \times \theta_{1} \\ &=20 \times 20 \times\left(T_{h 2}-T_{c 1}\right) \\ &=400(300-280)=8000 \mathrm{kW} \\ \text{also }\quad Q&=m_{c} c_{p c}\left(T_{c 2}-T_{c 1}\right) \\ \therefore \quad 8000 &=0.4 \times 1000\left(T_{c 2}-280\right) \\ 20&=T_{c 2}-280 \\ \text{or}\quad T_{c 2}&=300^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned} [/latex] Alternatively: Given data: [latex] A=20 \mathrm{m}^{3} ; U=20 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} ; \quad [/latex] [latex] c_{\mathrm{ph}}=1000 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} [/latex] [latex] m_{c}=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} ; \quad T_{c 1}=280 \mathrm{K} ; \quad m_{h}=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] [latex] T_{h 2}=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{c 2}=?[/latex] By energy balance, Heat lost by hot fluid = Heat gained by cold fluid [latex] m_{h} c_{p h}\left(T_{h 1}-T_{h 2}\right)=m_{c} c_{p c}\left(T_{c 2}-T_{c 1}\right) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { or } T_{h 1}-T_{h 2} &=T_{c 2}-T_{c 1} \qquad \because m_{h} c_{p h}=m_{c} c_{p c} \\ T_{h 1}-300 &=T_{c 2}-280 \\ T_{h 1}-T_{c 2} &=300-280 \qquad \ldots(1) \\ T_{h 1}-T_{c 2} &=20 \\ \epsilon&=\frac{N T U}{N T U+1} \quad[ \text{For balancing heat exchanger}]\\ \frac{T_{h 1}-T_{h 2}}{T_{h 1}-T_{c 1}} &=\frac{1}{1+1} \\ \frac{T_{h 1}-300}{T_{h 1}-280} &=\frac{1}{2} \\ 2 T_{h 1}-600 &=T_{h 1}-280 \\ T_{h 1} &=600-280=320 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned} [/latex] Substitute the value of [latex]T_{h 1}=320 \mathrm{K} [/latex] in Eq. (1), we get [latex] 320-T_{c 2}=20 [/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad T_{c 2}=300 \mathrm{K}[/latex]

question: Question 43 A cylindrical uranium fuel rod of radius 5 mm in a nuclear reactor is generating heat at the rate of [latex]4\times 10^{7} Wm^{3}[/latex] . The rod is cooled by a liquid (convective heat transfer coefficient 1000 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]-K) at  [latex]25^{\circ}C[/latex]. At steady state, the surface temperature (in K) of the rod is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} r&=5 \mathrm{mm}=0.005 \mathrm{m}\\ \therefore \quad &=2 r=2 \times 0.005=0.010 \mathrm{m} \\ q_{G} &=4 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ h_{0} &=1000 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \\ T_{0} &=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] For steady state heat transfer, Rate of heat generation in the rod = rate of convection heat transfer from rod surface to fluid [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{G} \times \text { volume of } \operatorname{rod} &=h_{0} A\left(T_{s}-T_{0}\right) \\ q_{G} \times \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} l^{\prime} &=h_{0} \times \pi d l\left(T_{s}-T_{0}\right) \\ \frac{d q_{G}}{4} &=h_{0}\left(T_{s}-T_{0}\right) \\ \frac{0.010 \times 4 \times 10^{7}}{4} &=1000\left(T_{s}-25\right) \\ \text{or }\quad T_{s}-25 &=100\\ \text{or }\quad T_{s}&=100+25=125^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\\ &=(125+273) \mathrm{K}=398 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 Work is done on an adiabatic system due to which its velocity changes from 10 m/s to 20 m/s, elevation increases by 20 m and temperature increases by 1 K. The mass of the system is 10 kg,  [latex]C_{v}[/latex]  = 100 J/(kg.K) and gravitational acceleration is 10 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex] . If there is no change in any other component of the energy of the system, the magnitude of total work done (in kJ) on the system is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \delta Q&=d E+\delta W \\ 0&=\Delta U+\Delta K \cdot E+\Delta P \cdot E+\delta W \\ 0&=m c_{v} d T+\frac{1}{2} m\left(V_{2}^{2}-V_{1}^{2}\right)+m g \\ &\qquad +(z_{2}-z_{1})+\delta W\\ 0&=10 \times 0.1 \times 1+\frac{1}{2} \times 10\left((20)^{2}-(10)^{2}\right) \times 10^{-3} \\ &\qquad +10 \times 10 \times 20 \times 10^{-3}+\delta W \\ \therefore \quad \delta W&=-4.5 \mathrm{kJ} \\ &=4.5 \mathrm{kJ}, \text{work don on the system} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 One kg of air (R = 287 J/kg-K) undergoes an irreversible process between equilibrium state 1      ([latex]20^{\circ}[/latex]C, 0.9 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] ) and equilibrium state 2 ([latex]20^{\circ}[/latex]C, 0.6 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] ). The change in entropy [latex]s_{2}[/latex]-[latex]s_{1}[/latex] (in J/kg-K)    is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} s_{2}-s_{1} &=c_{v} \ln \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}+R \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \\ &=R \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \quad \because T_{1}=T_{2} \\ &=287 \ln \frac{0.6}{0.9}=-116.368 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 For the same values of peak pressure, peak temperature and heat rejection, the correct order of efficiencies for Otto, Dual and Diesel cycles is
solution: For same peak pressure, peak temperature and heat rejection [latex]\eta_{Dieseal}\gt\eta_{Dual}\gt\eta_{Otto}[/latex] For same compression ratio and heat rejection [latex]\eta_{Otto}\gt\eta_{Dual}\gt\eta_{Dieseal}[/latex]

question: Question 47 In a Rankine cycle, the enthalpies at turbine entry and outlet are 3159 kJ/kg and 2187 kJ/kg, respectively. If the specific pump work is 2 kJ/kg, the specific steam consumption (in kg/kW-h) of the cycle based on net output is _______________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} w_{\text {turbine }} &=h_{1}-h_{2} \\ &=(3159-2187) \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ w_{\text {net }} &=w_{\text {turbine }}-w_{\text {pump }} \\ &=972-2=970 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Specific steam consumption [latex] =\frac{3600}{970} \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kWh}=3.711 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kWh}[/latex] Specific steam consumption is amount of steam required to produce 1 kWh(or) 3600 kJ of work.

question: Question 48 A cube and a sphere made of cast iron (each of volume 1000 [latex]cm^{3}[/latex]) were cast under identical conditions.  The time taken for solidifying the cube was 4 s. The solidification time (in s) for the sphere is __________
solution: Time of solidification(T) [latex] \begin{array}{l} =k\left[\frac{\text { volume }}{\text { surface area }}\right]^{2} \\ {\left[\begin{array}{l} \left.\frac{T_{\text {sphere }}}{T_{\text {cube }}}\right]=\left[\frac{A_{\text {cube }}}{A_{\text {sphere }}}\right]^{2}=\left[\frac{6 a^{2}}{4 / 3 \pi r^{3}}\right]^{2}-(1) \end{array}\right.}\\ \because\left[V_{\text {sphere }}=V_{\text {cube }}\right] \\ V_{\text {cube }}=a^{3}=1000 \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\ \therefore \qquad a =10\mathrm{cm}\\ V_{\text {sphere }}=\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}=1000\\ \Rightarrow \qquad r=6.2035 \mathrm{cm} \\ \end{array}[/latex] Putting in Eq.(1), we get [latex] \frac{T_{\text {sphere }}}{T_{\text {cube }}}=\left[\frac{6 \times 10^{2}}{4 \pi \times(6.2035)^{2}}\right]^{2} [/latex] [latex] T_{\text {sphere }} =6.157355 \mathrm{seconds}[/latex]

question: Question 49 In a two-stage wire drawing operation, the fractional reduction (ratio of change in cross-sectional area to initial cross-sectional area) in the first stage is 0.4. The fractional reduction in the second stage is 0.3. The overall fractional reduction is
solution: Fractional reduction in first stage [latex] =\frac{\text { Change in area in first stage }}{\text { Original area }(A) \text { before reduction }} [/latex] [latex] 0.4=\frac{\text { Change in area in first stage }}{A} [/latex] Change in area in first stage [latex]=0.4 \mathrm{A}[/latex] Area after first redirection [latex] =A-0.4 A=0.6 A [/latex] Fraction reduction in second stage [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{\text { Change in area in second stage }}{\text { Original area before second stage }} \\ 0.3=\frac{\text { Change in area in second stage }}{0.6 \mathrm{A}} \end{array}[/latex] Change in after 2 nd stage [latex]=0.18 A [/latex] Remaining area after 2nd reduction [latex] \begin{array}{l} =0.60 .18 \mathrm{A} \\ =0.42 \mathrm{A} \end{array}[/latex] Overall reduction in area [latex] =A-0.42 A=0.58 A[/latex] Overall fractional reduction [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{\text { Overall reduction in area }}{\text { Original area }} \\ =\frac{0.58 \mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{A}}=0.58 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 50 The flow stress (in MPa) of a material is given by [latex]\sigma=500\varepsilon^{0.1}[/latex] ; where [latex]\varepsilon[/latex] is true strain. The Young's modulus of elasticity of the material is 200 GPa. A block of thickness 100 mm made of this material is compressed to 95 mm thickness and then the load is removed. The final dimension of the block (in mm) is _________
solution: Equating the stress to the equation up to elastic limit, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma &=500 \varepsilon^{0.1}=200 \times 10^{3} \times \varepsilon \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\varepsilon^{0.9} &=\frac{500}{200 \times 10^{3}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \varepsilon(\text { tuestain })&=1.28476 \times 10^{-3}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \varepsilon_{T}&=\ln (1+\varepsilon)\\ \varepsilon(\text { engg.strain })_{\text {upto elastic limit }}&=1.285586 \times 10^{-3}=\frac{\Delta L}{L} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad(\Delta L)_{\text {upto elastic limit }}&=0.128558 \mathrm{mm}\\ \Rightarrow \qquad & \text{Final dimension of block} \\ &=95+ \text{ elastic recover}\\ &=95.128558 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 During a TIG welding process, the arc current and arc voltage were 50 A and 60 V, respectively, when the welding speed was 150 mm/min. In another process, the TIG welding is carried out at a welding speed of 120 mm/min at the same arc voltage and heat input to the material so that weld quality remains the same. The welding current (in A) for this process is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{50 \times 60}{150} &=\frac{I \times 60}{120} \\ I &=\frac{50 \times 12}{155}=40 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 A single point cutting tool with [latex]0^{\circ}[/latex] rake angle is used in an orthogonal machining process. At a cutting speed of 180 m/min, the thrust force is 490 N. If the coefficient of friction between the tool and the chip is 0.7, then the power consumption (in kW) for the machining operation is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{F}{N}&=\frac{F_{T}}{F_{C}}=0.7\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{490}{F_{C}} &=0.7 \\ F_{C} &=700 \mathrm{N} \\ \text { Power } &=F_{C} \times V=\frac{700 \times 180}{60} \\ &=2.1 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 A resistance-capacitance relaxation circuit is used in an electrical discharge machining process. The discharge voltage is 100 V. At a spark cycle time of 25 [latex]\mu[/latex]s, the average power input required is  1 kW. The capacitance (in [latex]\mu[/latex]F) in the circuit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Power } &=\frac{\text { Work }}{\text { Time }} \\ P &=\frac{1}{2} \frac{C V^{2}}{t} \\ \Rightarrow \quad C &=\frac{P \times 2 t}{V^{2}}=\frac{1000 \times 2 \times 25 \times 10^{-6}}{(100)^{2}} \\ &=5 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A project consists of 7 activities. The network along with the time durations (in days) for various activities is shown in the figure. The minimum time (in days) for completion of the project is_________
solution: The critical path is 1-2-4-5-6 of 40 Days duration.

question: Question 55 A manufacturer has the following data regarding a product: Fixed cost per month = Rs. 50000 Variable cost per unit = Rs. 200 Selling price per unit = Rs. 300 Production capacity = 1500 units per month If the production is carried out at 80% of the rated capacity, then the monthly profit (in Rs.)            is ____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Production } &=0.8 \times 1500=1200 \\ \text { Profit } &=S-V-F \\ &=1200 \times 300-1200 \times 200-50000 \\ &=70,000 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 61 Ram and Shyam shared a secret and promised to each other that it would remain between them. Ram expressed himself in one of the following ways a given in the choices below. Identify the correct way as per standard English.

options.A: It would remain between you and me.
options.B: It would remain between I and you.
options.C: It would remain between you and I.

question: Question 62 In the following question,the first and last sentence of the passage are in order and numbered 1 and 6. The rest of passage is split in 4 parts and numbered as 2, 3, 4 and 5. These four parts are not arranged in proper order. Read the sentences and arrange them in a logical sentence to make a passage and choose the correct sequence from the given options. 1. On Diwali, the family rises early in the morning 2. The whole family, including young and old enjoy doing this 3. Children let off fireworks later in the night with their friends 4. At sunset, the lamps are lit and family performs many rituals 5. Father, mother and children visit relatives and exchange sweets 6. Houses looks so pretty with lighted lamps all around

Question 65 Ms.X will be in Bagdogra from 01/05/2014 to 20/05/2014 and from 22/05/2014 to 31/05/2014.On the morning of 21/5/2104, she will reach Kochi via Mumbai. Which of the statement below is logically valid and can be inferred from the above sentence?

options.A: Ms.X will be in Kochi for one day,only in May.
options.B: Ms.X will be in Kochi for only one day,only in May.
options.C: Ms.X will be only in Kochi for one day,only in May.
options.D: Only Ms.X will be in Kochi for one day in May.
